lesson.title: After consonants
lesson.shortDescription: Vowels can be on the right side of consonants.
lesson.description:
In Tai Dam, a syllable starts with a consonant. If the vowel is a post-position form, it's written right next to the consonant, without any space in between. Imagine a right-vowel syllable that looks like this: ùê∂ + ùëâ.
So:
  Í™Ä + Í™± becomes Í™ÄÍ™± ("kaa"),
  Í™Å + Í™Ω becomes Í™ÅÍ™Ω ("kan"),
and
  Í™â + Í™∫ becomes Í™âÍ™∫ ("ngua").

lesson.title: Above consonants
lesson.shortDescription: Vowels can appear above consonants in syllables.
lesson.description:
Some Tai Dam vowels can sit above the consonant they follow. Start with the base consonant on the writing line, then place the vowel sign directly above it to finish the syllable‚Äîno extra marks are added to the left or right. For example,
  Í™ä + Í™≤ becomes Í™äÍ™≤ ("chi")
  Í™é + Í™≥ becomes Í™éÍ™≥ ("su"),
and
  Í™ê + Í™∑ becomes Í™êÍ™∑ ("hgno").

lesson.title: More practice
lesson.shortDescription: Extended practice with vowels that appear to the right and above consonants in Tai Dam syllables.
lesson.description: Extended practice with vowels that appear to the right and above consonants in Tai Dam syllables.

lesson.title: Multi-part vowels (Before and above consonants)
lesson.shortDescription: Extended practice with vowels that appear to the left and above consonants in Tai Dam syllables.
lesson.description:
Some Tai Dam vowels have two parts. These parts can appear before and above the consonant they belong to in a syllable. Imagine a left-vowel syllable that looks like this: ùëâ‚ÇÅ + ùê∂ + ùëâ‚ÇÇ.
So:
  Í™π + Í™é becomes Í™πÍ™é ("sue"),
  Í™πÍ™∑ + Í™Å becomes Í™πÍ™ÅÍ™∑ ("koe"),
and
  Í™πÍ™∏ + Í™é becomes Í™πÍ™éÍ™∏ ("se").

lesson.title: Below consonants, Multi-part before & after
lesson.shortDescription: Vowels can appear below consonants, and some vowels have two parts which appear before and after consonants in Tai Dam syllables.
lesson.description:
Tai Dam vowels can also sit below the consonant they belong to in a syllable. Vowels can also appear in combination before a consonant and after it. Imagine a syllable that looks like this: ùëâ‚ÇÅ + ùê∂ + ùëâ‚ÇÇ.
So:
  Í™é +  Í™¥ becomes Í™éÍ™¥ ("su"),
and
  Í™π + Í™é + Í™± becomes Í™πÍ™éÍ™± ("saw").

lesson.title: Review
lesson.shortDescription: A comprehensive review of all consonants and vowels introduced in previous lessons.
lesson.description: A review lesson covering all consonants and vowels introduced in previous lessons.

lesson.title: Pre-consonant dipthongs
lesson.shortDescription: This lesson introduces three vowels (-ay, -a∆∞, -oh) and six consonants (f, 'f, m, 'm, y, 'y).
lesson.description: This lesson introduces three vowels (-ay, -a∆∞, -oh) and six consonants (f, 'f, m, 'm, y, 'y). The vowels ai and ae appear before the consonant, while oo also appears before the consonant. You'll practice combining these to form syllables like 'fay' (fire) and 'ma∆∞' (new).

lesson.title: Review
lesson.shortDescription: A comprehensive review of all consonants and vowels introduced in previous lessons.
lesson.description: A review lesson covering all consonants and vowels introduced in previous lessons.

lesson.title: Consonants: l, v
lesson.shortDescription: This lesson introduces two new consonants: l and v.
lesson.description: This lesson introduces two new consonants: l and v. You'll learn how to combine these consonants with previously learned vowels to form syllables such as 'la' and 'vo'.

lesson.title: Consonants: h, vowel initial glottal
lesson.shortDescription: This lesson introduces two new consonnants: h and glottal stop (').
lesson.description: This lesson introduces two new consonnants: h and glottal stop ('). You'll learn how to combine these consonants with previously learned vowels to form syllables such as 'ha' and ''a'.

combinations.description: Combining low vowel initial glottal with the vowel 'ay', like in 'ice'
Combining high vowel initial glottal with the vowel 'ay', like 'eye'

lesson.title: Tones marks
lesson.shortDescription: The tone marks, mai ek (Í™ø) and mai tho (Í´Å), are introduced in this lesson.
lesson.description:
The tone marks, mai ek (Í™ø) and mai tho (Í´Å), are introduced in this lesson. They appear above the consonant, and whether the consonant is high or low determines the actual tone value.

Tai Dam has six tones:
1 - low mid,
2 - high rising,
3 - low falling,
4 - high,
5 - high-mid,
6 - mid-falling.

With open syllables, mai ek (Í™ø) is second tone (high-rising) for high class consonants and fifth tone (high-mid) for low class consonants.

With open syllables, mai tho (Í´Å) is the third tone (low-falling) for low class consonants and sixth tone (mid-falling) for high class consonants.

combinations.description: No tone indicator so this is an even tone. It means the intonation doesn't rise or fall.

Mai ek (Í™ø) when paired with a high consonant, like Í™Ä, is the second tone (high-rising) as in Í™ºÍ™ÄÍ™ø (chicken).

When paired with a low consonant, like Í™ú, it is the fifth tone (high-mid) as in older sibling

Mai tho (Í´Å) with a low consonant is the third tone (low-falling) as in Í™πÍ™ÑÍ´ÅÍ™± (rice).

With a high consonant, it is the sixth tone (mid-falling) as in Í™ôÍ™æÍ´Å (water)
